10/ For products in frontier tech (drones to VR to autonomous cars etc) I expect teams w/ great software AND hardware talent to win big.
9/ And frankly, finding, recruiting, & helping retain hardware 2.0 talent is an area where top h/w investors can differentiate from others.
8/ There are few who know how to ship hardware 2.0 products. Those few are incredible resources for startups that are able to get them.
7/ Consumers today have such high demands from hardware devices, and expect so much. Its hardware 2.0. Not your daddy's hardware anymore :)
6/ But that's not true! No wonder many hardware projects don't ship, don't succeed, & don't scale. Hardware is hard & little details matter.
5/ To a naive eye it might look like bunch of designers came up with a cool design & got it made in China...and magic is in software alone.
4/ ...that are required to put a quality product in customers' hands, in time, at the right price, and with the right service guarantees.
3/ But that would be inaccurate. Only those who  see sausage-making from the inside know painstaking efforts put into hardware engineering.
2/ Because there are digital interfaces to such 'devices' (apps, voice UI etc) some people might call it 'software wrapped in plastic'!

14/ Entreps are noticing these advances, and rapidly imagining + building the future we will live in. It is happening fast. It is awesome.
13/ Such a future doesn't have to be all Big Brother-y. It can also be private, where AI made us feel our 6th sense was actually real.
12/ ...image and voice sensors seamlessly analyze spaces and activity for us, and our decisions are always supported by tons of data.
11/ It is easy to fast forward and visualize a world where smart sensors were embedded in every dumb surface we see around us...
10/ As cost of sensors, connectivity and compute approach zero, what kind of future can we envision? This is where Lux is spending time now.
9/ ...and physicians make smart decisions (@cloudMedX).
8/  ...medical devices (@3ScanTweets) and AR/VR (@Matterport). GPUs are literally helping the blind see (eg see @clarifai and @airaio)...
7/ From self-driving cars (stealth) & drones (@cyphyworksinc) to home automation (stealth), physical security systems (@EvolvTechnology)...
6/ Use of GPU compute + ML/AI is now almost ubiquitous in h/w startups. Most recent Lux portfolio companies are part of this revolution.
5/ Between on-device AI & in-the-cloud AI, all kinds of hardware systems are becoming intelligent. They can see, learn, find their own way.
4/ one could argue deep learning is the future of ALL computation. As @cdixon says, to consider it a SV buzzword would be at your own peril.
3/ Not enough has been said about the rise of GPU computing. NVIDIA stands to be a big winner but others may catch up. (cc: @wolfejosh)
2/ Future is indeed purpose built hardware systems mostly with cell phone components + software + connectivity + data-enabled intelligence.

9/ In the meantime lets share our learnings broadly. We all benefit when we share best practices. RESPECT to all those who already do.
8/ Again, point is not to pay high prices. They NEEDED to come down. Point is to raise the bar for people we back, & how we help companies.
7/ Venture returns won't get made whether we paid $4m or $6m cap...but whether we backed the best people and rolled up our sleeves to help.
6/ Yes it makes sense to negotiate more sane prices of early stage rounds...but getting caught up in that may be missing the bigger picture.
5/ If anything, as other 'tourist investors' flee, it will become easier to get behind top entrepreneurs building great companies with $$.
4/ As we feel a bearish outlook in the short term, it's time to look harder for those gems and double down on them & invest w/ conviction.
3/ Great companies get started every year. And venture remains a business where $$ get made when you invest in those outstanding companies.
2/ Others are closer to particular shenanigans happening that adversely affect seed investors, but I feel we need to play the long game.

10/ Be the gorilla. Check out this Andy Rachleff essay on market leadership: https://t.co/oe8YLEfzcp
9/ Don't play to play. Play to win.
8/ Suck oxygen out of the air. Raise capital, strike big partnership, acquihire top talent, stay on message/brand and tell your story.
7/ Give your core customers what they want, and are willing to pay for. You can't win by spreading resources thin/adding tons of features.
6/ Focus on your roadmap and vision. Communicate clearly with team and the market - this is your tribe. Stay nimble.
5/ Execute offensive strategies. Don't sit and wait. Hire away key talent maybe?
4/ Plan defensive strategies. Protect your team, customers, patents, messaging.
3/ Never underestimate competition. Speaking badly about competitors never helps. In fact hurts your credibility.
2/ Understand your competition, their strengths/weaknesses. What can you learn from them.
'Dealing with competitors: Do not play to play. Play to win.' https://t.co/huQnT43M8j

@financedfuture Also privacy issues, cost issues, most techniques require human intervention & a manual security process flow.
12/ Lots of questions, few great answers. But security industry hard at work analyzing, learning, deploying the tools they have access to.
11/ Should we screen for both metal and non-metal threats at all facilities? Airport like screening processes? Facial recognition?
10/ Unfortunately global sharing of best practices is not routine. Esp for soft targets. Should every facility have a security director?
9/ But technology is our friend in this war on terror. We need it to work better, and for state of the art to be shared broadly, worldwide.
8/ New tools and technologies are being developed and tested. They won't be perfect and can't work in isolation from other societal factors.
7/ There will be lots of analysis of what happened in Paris. What tech worked, and where systems failed. What info or prep could be better.
6/ A suicide bomber was stopped at the door when he was patted down. And stadium was organized to do controlled evacuation. Kudos to staff.
5/ None of us want to go through everyday life as constantly being surveilled or searched. But such tech potentially saved hundreds of lives
4/ Security at public venues, such as stadiums, is getting beefed up...but there is still a long way to go. From screening to reaction.
3/ Public spaces globally are at risk. Spaces that weren't considered as such. For eg sports events: Boston marathon, Paris Stadium etc.
2/ It is an unfortunate reality that we are increasingly living in a world threatened by those who seek to hurt innocent people en masse
1/ As an investor in @EvolvTechnology that aims to protect physical spaces against threats, I am reading articles on Paris attacks carefully

7/ As often stated, drone industry is at its infancy & hyped. But customer focused companies, like CyPhy, can emerge as category winners.
6/ And surely delivery drones would be highly engineered, robust, durable systems with high accuracy controls and navigation.
5/ Consumers need a drone camera to carry in their bagpack. No complicated gimbals or radio controllers. LVL1 provides that.
4/ Mining/fire-safety professionals etc use pocket flyers - carried in your pockets and launched to 'look ahead' & 'around the corner'
3/ Commercial enterprises need lighter weight systems for long duration flights with dedicated sensors for agriculture, construction etc.
2/ Public safety professionals need systems that can stay in air for hours, days, weeks. Local satellites for imaging or communication hubs.
1/ CyPhy builds robots - that fly - hardware/software/data systems to solve real problems for its customers.

10/ ...and these days, it might take the 'global village' to help parents give the best to their kids. Let's pitch in whenever we can.
9/ I don't have answers but I know that just like @semil, fathers everywhere are trying to be good dads. It does take a village though...
8/ I see those photos of refugee kids and it tears my heart...what must their parents feel. Or kids in poverty, hunger, and war anywhere.
7/ I can go on...but I know I'm privileged. I have means to find help when in need. I have family that can help...others are not so lucky.
6/ But because I miss these kids when I am away. I hug them tightly before every flight as who knows if I will ever see them again :(
5/ I have two kids, and a superwoman as their mom. I have always traveled a lot for work, but it gets tougher now. Not b/c I get tired.
4/ But should I make everyone around me adjust their own busy lives to fit mine? Would even that make me feel I'm giving enough to the kids?
3/ Am I a good dad? Do I give enough time to my kids? For eg. I am at a Board mtg in LA on Eid - Muslim equivalent of Christmas. Ugh.
2/ All of us fathers are in the same situation. Its a constant balancing act. And there is simple never enough time in the day.

@Arusha_Imtiaz early stage startup is a lot of sausage making. A lot of unknowns. A lot of fear but also a lot of "I hope we get lucky".
6/ Unfortunately I see too many entrepreneurs who don't fully realize this. Hence I'm not surprised many h/w kickstarters don't deliver.
5/ And you may get lucky & deliver which will be awesome. But be careful and transparent. Trust w/ customer lost once is hard to restore.
4/ Those paying you in crowdfunding $$ are customers. They expect a great product. On time, w/ great service. They will cut you some slack.
3/ That's probably not a good time to raise Crowdfunding dollars on the basis of a slick video. It can come back to bite you bad.
2/ You can't raise investment dollars for your idea. You can't hire best ppl b/c you are yourself not convinced of the merits of your idea.
